description: Part of the excitement of going to Noah's is you're never quite sure what you will receive. Order an egg-mitt, open the bag and discover a bear claw! Sweet, I wanted a bear claw anyway. Not really, but I'm constantly amazed here. What baffles me even more is for the most part the staff is cool and friendly. Maybe its a front. Regardless, when my egg-mitt is right (I'll guess two out of five times) and the Chelsea coffee is fresh, its a great little meal on the run.
author: Rob B.

description:
Who are you anyways, Noah?

   You, who has just taken away your employee's rights to tips without increasing their hourly wage, cowering at the recent Starbucks class-action ruling, and retaliating with a most unnecessary blow to your entire workforce.  

   You, who turns out some funkdafied hummus.  If I wanted whole garbanzo beans on my bagel, I'd make it at home, not pay you four dollars for it.

   You, who is located in the epicenter of the DPT Militia warzone, a landscape so scarred by the stomping of feet and echoes of expletives, even the most seasoned veterans cringe at it's mention.

   You, who puts blemished fruit in white tea and calls it "Limited Edition Infusion".  I know rotten fruit when I see it, and I know you need to get rid of it.  But I'm not buying it. 

  None of these things are the fault of your staff, who are fabulous.  Four glowing stars for them, and all my worldly shame just for you, Noah.  You jerk.
author: Lea N.

description: I had a bad experience at this place a month + ago,  just found my receipt and it reminded me. We had a school event early on a Saturday morning, so the afternoon before I went in and ordered and paid for a Grab and Go dozen and the cream cheese  I asked if I should call ahead the next morning and they said  "You can call but we won't answer the phone".  I asked if I would need to wait in line and they said "no, we will put up here"  (above the counter).  when I arrived the next day about 30 minutes after the place opened, there was a huge line, which I waited in for about 10 minutes and I finally went to the front and showed my receipt. The cashier pointed to a box and said- "that's it". Well, it wasn't it!  The box was full of onion and other flavors not requested.   The kids did not eat the onion bagels. What a waste of time and money.  I did try to call the next day and sure enough: "no one answered" the phone.
author: Meg F.

description:
One star for making a bagel in such a way that i happen to like (chewy)
the other four stars are not there for it being unclean , no soy milk for the latte,,they couldn't break my large bill , the general low moral and that the bageldog costs $4.55  tsk tsk

Being in there reminded me of visiting my former communist Czechoslovakia. One would think that for the Marina they could spiffy things up a bit.
author: Barb L.

description:
I recently used Noah's for breakfast catering for meetings.  I ordered bagels, pastries, and coffee for three mornings.

The first morning the bagels were not sliced.  I specifically asked for sliced bagels, and it was even on their order form!  But nothing was sliced.  I let my catering contact know.

Second morning the bagels were sliced.  The delivery guy dropped them off and ran out the door.  There were no schmears!  I had to call my catering contact and wait 30 minutes before someone delivered schmears (and they only brought two kinds).  I was never given a receipt for my order, nor was I asked to sign anything since it was on my credit card.  I had to ask my catering contact to send me something.

Complaints started coming in about the coffee.  It was weak and watered down.  It looked like tea!  Again, I let my catering contact at Noah's know.  He assured me it wouldn't happen again.

Third day the majority if the bagels were sliced.  There were schmears.  The coffee was strong enough.  However, there was no receipt.  Again, they didn't have anything for me to sign or even to use for my expense report!  I had to contact me catering contact to get things fixed.

And what did Noah's do to try and keep us as a customer?  Nothing.  No discount.  No coupons.  We paid for inferior service.  For things to go wrong three days in a row, you'd think they'd want to do something to make up for their mistakes in hopes of keeping us as a customer.

We will be ordering from another business next time we need breakfast for meetings.
author: Keith P.

description: Noah's bagels has always been my favorite bagel joint. I love to get them fresh in the morning, and usually have a sesame or asiago cheese bagel with plain shmeer, cucumbers and lettuce, or just smoked salmon shmeer. I'm not typically a morning person but on those few rare occasions I'll grab a bagel from here with a smoothie from jamba juice for breakfast *yumo*.
author: Petra S.

description:
Eh, this place is just OK. Sure, I'll eat here if one of my friends (Ali) prefers this place over another bagel joint but definitely not my first, or second choice, for that matter.

I'm a butter whore and they never put enough butter. Ever. Sometimes it doesn't even taste like there's any butter at all. Oh wait...that's because they only buttered one side of my bagel. Yes folks, it's true. They put butter on one side and then slap the other side on top and cut it in half. Dry, toasted bagels just are not appetizing.

So, now I have to specifically ask them to please butter both sides and they probably think I'm a freak but I don't care. And I don't tend to ask for extra butter because then it's like completely drenched and it just feels wrong. 

And I hate their blueberry bagels. I can't put my finger on the reason why exactly but I just don't like them. I've had a million way better blueberry bagels than at Noah's.

Noah's is kind of like a Baja Fresh or something. It's not the best you've tasted and you know there's better and more authentic alternatives, but you'll take it in a pinch.
author: Kristin R.

description:
If it weren't for Lox, I wouldn't step foot in Noahs.  A message to the 15 year olds working there this summer:
"I know you close in 15 minutes.  Stop rolling your eyes, circle what I want on your little order pad, give me my $6 bagel and pickle, and can the attitude you minimum wage earnin' twerp."
author: Patrick A.

description:
Dear Noah's,

Could you make a simple bagel more poorly? I ordered one with cream cheese (sorry, schmear), tomato and avocado. The schmear was so light that it was like melted butter, and the avocado was 2 teaspoons of guacamole spread. I paid almost a dollar more for this? Aren't fresh avocados available in California? I can only imagine what I would have gotten if I asked for their "light" version.

The one star is for your friendly staff. Otherwise, thanks for a bad, expensive breakfast.
author: H N.

description: Great selection of bagels. Love their breakfast bagels with egg, cheese, butter and chives. Their muffins are some of the best i've ever had. Wish they served iced coffee drinks.
author: Anne L.

description: I've been getting lunch at Noah's bagel ever since I started working at Goodbyes Consignment Shop on May 2007. It's the cheapest place to get lunch in the Laurel Village. I love the Asiago bagels with cream cheese and chicken :)
author: CeeCee M.

description: I feel like Noah's Bagels are the Walgreen's of bagel shops; they are everywhere in this city and more tolerated than loved. I come to this location every so often for my lunch breaks and I'm always just a little disappointed. Everything is just kind of below average. The coffee is drinkable, but not enjoyable. The bagels themselves are pretty good, but the bagel sandwiches are not. I usually end up getting the bacon and cheese egg sandwich and everything except the bagel tastes like it could have come from McDonald's. My suggestion is to stick to the bagels and cream cheese and you'll have no idea that it's actually a pretty terrible place.
author: Jeremy J.

description:
Seeing as Noah's is one of the few bagel places that are reliably good I come here often. I like getting some sort of cheese bagel with cream cheese, tomatoes, cucumber, salt and pepper and cut in half. 

At this Noah's you have to ask them to cut it in half. It's hard to eat and drive when they aren't cut in half. 

At this Noah's you have to check to see if you got the core of the tomato. YUCK!!!!!!!!! I DESPISE TOMATO CORES IN MY BAGEL. How gross is it to be enjoy your delicious bagel and suddenly bite into a tomato core. The other Noah's core them, can Noah not afford the time or the money on making their employees core their tomatoes? I have contemplated writing them numerous times to complain about this. 

Also... this is Laurel Village, so be prepared to be accosted by 30 year old skinny new moms in athletic gear with a double stroller. This is the Rodeo Dr. of young moms. So if fresh MILFs are your thing... hang out here. Sometimes I have this urge to wear an empire shirt and a pillow in my jeans and hang out here. Just to see what happens. Instead I'll just keep eating bagels and I won't need the pillow. 

Parking tip: Free on Sundays in the meters but the back always has spaces and if you park by the Book sign you can walk right out to Noah's through the tunnel. 

No credit card minimum. A definite plus!
author: Ali R.

description:
Four stars for their bagel selection in the morning and their salmon cream cheese spread.  I've only been able to make it there before 2 PM once, so there were many bagels to choose from.  After that, selection is very limited.  I buy them by the half dozen and slice them and freeze them.

Their cream cheese spread is really good.  I used to buy Philadelphia brand at the supermarkets, but now I get them at Noah's and am taken with the salmon cream cheese, especially.
author: Mrs F.

description:
PANINI REVIEW.  panini only.  nO BAGEL REVIEW. JUST THE PANINI.
Tuna. Hot. Cheese. Spicy. Sweet. Sour. Crunchy. Hot. Fresh. Mayo. Gooey. Hot and crunchy. happy happy happy
F A N T A S T I C.

and of course, lines suck, service is somewhat mediocre, too crowded, not really good bagels, BUT THE PANINININININII!
author: Nini M.

description: Bread with a hole in it does not a bagel make.  Even if you season it well.
author: Indigo S.

description:
My coworker/chauffeur and I are in this place at least 3 times a week. They're quite stingy with the cream cheese, the bagels, if uneaten in 30 seconds of getting it, seem untoasted almost soggy, and the staff sometimes has off days when it comes to being nice. 

Other than that, I do love their coffee and I do crave their soggy bagels. Especially, Asiago with strawberry cream cheese....mmmm.

UPDATE: 8/5 
 
1st: They received a 75 on their Inspection Score Card... DISGUSTING! I've seen hole-in-the-wall Chinese food restaurants with better scores than that!!
 
2nd: They were out of small coffee cups. I wanted a small but because they only had large cups I had to be charged for a large. What the fuck is that about? I doubt Noah's will go out of business for the 10 cents of extra coffee I might get in my large cup. 

3rd: They were out of strawberry cream cheese. Go to one of the other 6 Noah's in the city and take some. I've worked for food chains before, you can do this. 

4th: They were out of Hazelnut coffee. 

This business sells three basic things: coffee, bagels, and cream cheese. 

I believe I have stepped into this Noah's for the last time.
author: Emily H.

description:
Great noah's. A little bit smaller than other locations so not really a sit down and eat your bagel or breakfast or lunch. They have a few window counter top seats. Sometimes it's a little crowded when the line has to wrap around in the middle haha.

They work quickly and are friendly here.
author: upper d.

description:
PLEASE HIRE MORE PEOPLE!!!!!!  I know that they are the only bagel place in the neighborhood.  Hence, they have a lock on the market.  Rare is the time that I go to get a bagel.  I left that habit behind 15lbs ago and in college.  But, if I do opt to have one, all I ask is that I am given what I ordered and paid for.  The scene.  Saturday am, 11ish.  Monster line!!  I am standing there w/ my college roomie who is in town, she is a bagel freak.  I step up, and say, Extra toasted onion bagel w/ cucumber, tomato and cream cheese.  Great thanks, Nicole pay at the end.  AH, painless right?  Wrong.  I got half the order.  10 mins later, "Nicole!!!"  
As I open my wee pkg w/ anticipation.... Gasp, not toasted everything bagel w/ tomato.  What gives?  Am I asking for to much?  Mind you I was already in the car as this all happened, to late to go back for a fix up job....

PS- also change the lay out of the store, it is so cramped and does not flow at ALL!!!  Their spacial designer sucks!!
author: Nicole F.

description:
I love Noah's bagels.  They are delicious.  All I need is a blueberry bagel with cream cheese on the side and I'm happy!  Yum!

I have been craving bagels.  Not just any bagels.  Noah's bagels.  They are so yummy I even had a dream about Noah's bagels.  Must get me some today!
author: Stacey L.

description: Had Noah taken a supply of these leaden bagels on board the ark, it never would have stayed afloat.
author: Gourmet G.

description: Somehow got hooked on the Asiago Bagel Dog. Haven't had a bagel from here in a million years. Just tried a Blackberry Lemonade today, that was good. This, the end of my fragmentary sentences.
author: Ken L.

description:
it was " in" for a while
but I like New York style better.
Noah's are too sponge-like.
After chewing a bit, I feel like I am becoming a dog.
kind of boring to chew.
I think it is same difference between New York Pizza and Chicago pizza.
I do like New York pizza better.
But I have never been to New york and Chicago.
So, what do I know?
well, at least I am honest.
author: Nobu K.

description:
Either I was too hungry or lucky, but I actually had a more than decent Italian Chicken Panini there for lunch. Tasty, perfectly prepared and with great ingredients. Big change from the fake Paninis with disappointing breads I had several time in other San Francisco places.
I might get disappointed but I will get there again! :)
author: Cedrick C.

description: This location is always packed with loud little kids. Servers are friendly and the line moves pretty quickly.
author: Monika M.

description: Turkey sausage egg mitt on a sundried tomato bagel no chives please!
author: Tina L.

description: Good bagel joint. Quick service and they always have most bagels available even when it is later in the afternoon.
author: Darius A.

description: I prefer this bagel place over Posh or any other in the city I've tried so far. Get the asiago bagel with veggie spread. You won't need to eat for the rest of the day. Mmmmmm carbs.
author: Cathy T.

description: What can I say. Their bagels are pretty good (Sun dried tomato, Asiago cheese) but the GOURMET BAGELS are a little piece of heaven, namely the 6 Cheese and the Pesto cheese. WOW. The best shmears are Garlic Chive and Sun Dried Tomato. NICE. Pumpernickel bagel is good, too.
author: O K.

description: I've been going to Noah's since my Berkeley High days in the early 90's.  I have always thought the bagels were the BEST. This particular Noah's on California St always turns out the coldest and most rubbery bagels. PLEASE fix your toasters so it actually toasts the bagels.......the last 10 times (I know i should move on by now)I've gotten a cold, partially toasted bagel with either gobs of cream cheese or a glob of butter on one side. The only way I'll have a Noah's now is if I just buy it and toast it myself.
author: Mighty D.

description:
It's fall and the yummy pumpkin-related foods are arriving!  The pumpkin bagels at Noah's rock, as does the service at this store.

Unfortunately, I didn't catch her name, but the nice woman who rang us up not only shared our enthusiasm for all things pumpkin, but also gave us two free bagels!!  Nothing bad happened - this wasn't an attempt to smooth things over with a disgruntled customer.  We just chatted with her while she rang up our order.  Afterwards, I looked at my receipt and noticed I hadn't gotten charged for one of my bagels.  When I went back up and told her, she said "yeah, I know." (wink, wink)

SO NICE!!!  I didn't even notice that she gave us TWO free bagels with our order until I got home.  Many thanks to the nice pumpkin bagel lady at Noah's.  You made what had been a horrible morning so much better!
author: Jennifer S.

description: All Noah's bagels taste the same - super average, but that's what we have here in San Francisco. On that scale, I'd say this is a solid location. Service is reasonably efficient, they generally get my order right, and it's right in Laurel Village with a bunch of other chain establishments I can shamelessly take advantage of.
author: Kiesha R.

description: Their bagels are too fluffy, they never toast them enough, and they use whipped cream cheese.  All of this adds up to a sucky bagel.  Sometimes I eat here because I am right there and I forget how bad their bagels suck.  After one bite I remember their suckiness and wish that I went to House of Bagels instead.
author: Jake A.

description: I hadn't heard of Noah's until I move to SF, but apparently it is a good-sized chain.  Despite this fact, their bagels were pretty darn good and I easily enjoyed them.  If I can afford it, I prefer to go to House of Bagels on Geary, but when I am tight for money, I know I can get a tasty bagel here.
author: Victoria K.

description: I give this location 5 stars because the guy with the ponytail, whom I am assuming is the owner/manager always gives everyone service with a smile while he is seriously multi-tasking!   I like how efficient it is in here compared with other establishments of this class.  I luv the bagel dogs!!
author: Sue U.

description: these are the best bagels in the city.  they are soft and fresh and delicious.  the shop itself leaves something to be desired but get a sesame bagel with plain cream cheese and lox and you'll be a happy camper.  all the other places in the city have pretty bad bagels- posh, katz, house of bagels- not good!
author: Mick M.

description: I like Noah's for bagels in the Laurel Heights area. Service tends to be friendly and very decent. I like how fresh their bagels are and the variety of toppings. Parking can be a hassle if the area is busy. You might have more luck finding a spot on the rear side of the shops. A lot of the shops in the area have changed over the years but this place is still there.
author: Al B.

description: I usually like noah's bagel but it must be this location that I am not so in love with.People in this area are a bit loaded so they have a buch of kids come through here in the afternoon and they can be really loud and rude.Don't get me wrong ,I have nothing against these kids but they seem to have no manner at all.Not sure where their parents are and the people that work here never seem to want to say anything to them.People that work here seem to be real young too.Not only that they look so miserable and I can't wait that long for the snail service that they have here.The other location on fillmore are a lot nicer and they don't tolerate rich kids with loud mouth and attitude.
author: S F.

description: It happens everytime -- sticker shock. I forget how pricey it is, but then I take a bite into the egg/spinach/bacon panini and don't care. Really. It's so effing good. I wish this place had better seating -- there's three stools in the corner, that's about it. We went last weekend and decided to brave the cold outside and sit with my dog, who was having a barking hissyfit. Still, I love that damn panini for $8.
author: H H.

description: I will admit that I hit this place up often because I am a bagel lover!  Noah's makes the best bagels in the city, but they aren't always stocked full with my favorite.. the everything bagel.  I order the basic turkey sandwich but everytime, it is just the same and just the way I like it.  Its great to have bagels in the house so ordering half a dozen is cheap and easy.  This place is good but boring, I reccommend branching out in the city even though I just can't give it up.
author: Michelle N.

description: I only go here when I'm hungry and in Laurel heights, where I sometimes end up to grab some Peet's after one of my favorite running loops.  Every time I go, however, I wish I lived (or ran) closer to House of Bagels.  Noah's has gotten my order wrong several times (PUMPKIN not PUMPERNICKEL, please!) and their service is friendly but incredibly slow, even for a simple toasted bagel.  Not to mention the store is too tiny for everyone in line, everyone waiting for their slow-ass bagel sandwiches, and all their strollers, too.
author: Laura T.

description:
what can i say? i love bagels no matter where they're from.

i love how noah's bagels are fluffy, but sometimes are too chewy. and i do like whipped cream cheeses. sometimes, i get lunch here and usually get the tuna salad sandwich on marble rye. sandwiches are not bad. you can't go wrong with the swiss, spinach and mushroom egg-mit. toasted. with butter, pepper and chives.
author: Rosalee C.

description: Ohhhhh. The Asiago bagel with Sun-dried Tomato cream cheese...  That's whats up.
author: Robert M.

description: this is one place that is sure to put a smile on my face! living in Hawaii made me appreciate beagle shops especially Noahs (i can only think of 1 beagle shop on HI and its in boonville). There is nothing as good in the morning when you are hungry and on the go then getting the egg and cheddar on a toasted sesame beagle... oh its good ;) and the best part about this location is that its right next to Starbucks so you can get both guilty pleasures quick and easy.. mmmm
author: Barbara C.

description: Just discovered the egg and turkey bagel at noahs! I am addicted. Only downside the serving of milk is a bit small for the price.
author: Russ R.

description: I don't go to Noah's bagels for authentic bagels.  I don't think I've ever even had a real New York bagel, so I'd be doing fine with my fake bagels if it weren't such a pain to actually get one at this location.  Every time I come in its always a nightmare.  There was a fire in the toaster today.  I know because I was there, and I saw it.  Don't think you're just going to dash in and grab some quick breakfast.  Depending on how many people are there its about ten minutes.  That's a pretty long time since the toaster toasts it in, like, 10 seconds.  But I do like their bagel variety.  I'm glad to see chocolate chip is still around.  Back in the day Noah's used to sell chocolate babka, which was like chocolate challah bread, sort of.  The guy working there didn't even get what I was saying when I inquired about it at this location, which leads me to believe Noah's is no longer a proprietor of chocolate babka.  I don't know why, but I was surprised when I first learned they didn't have Noah's in New York City.  They have all that (fake) New York stuff in there, and what do I know, I grew up in San Francisco.
author: Emily X.

description: this place is awesome! i just like their bagels with peanut butter, or cream cheese it is delicious! (i dont usually order any special things like egg mits or panini's.)
author: neil r.

description: well ..... the staff are friendly and are super busy majority at the time. some service can be your worst but they also have their best moments... sandwiches are okay.. but bagel and cream chesse is good any time anyday! nothing unexpected...
author: Stephanie S.

description: This is the Noah's EVER.  The staff is rude and customer service is horrible!!!!   Save your self some aggrevation and go somewhere else, even if its farther away.  All of the employees are angry and rude!!
author: Michael F.

description: First of all, all "Noah's" are not created equal. I used to LOVE the Noah's Bagels in Washington DC on Wisconsin Ave in Georgetown. The ones in the Potrero Center and on Fillmore (in SF) were pretty good (4 stars - will write separate review). But, the Noah's Bagels in Laurel Village was really disappointing. I adore their chicken salad on a bagel, but it seems they changed the formula recently. It's no longer large, juicy pieces of white meat chicken in a delicious sauce. It's now small, chunky bits of meat (white?dark?) in a mayonnaise-y sauce. I got the Asiago Bagel w/ Chicken Salad today, and there were (seriously) 3 tiny pieces of chicken slathered in mediocre mayonaise on each half, covered with a massive and wilty piece of lettuce. It tasted alright, probably bc I was stahvin' and had just spent the past 3 hours at the Toyota dealership. Anyhow, it was a far cry from the juicy and luscious sandwich I used to get at Noah's in Georgetown. I didn't complain, but I prob won't be going to this Noah's again. I'll stick to Potrero or Fillmore.
author: Maren P.

description: RUDE RUDE RUDE, and outright foolish.  OK, so I don't carry cash -- it's not my fault that this joint doesn't make you sign when you pay via credit card, and since this is the case, there is no space to leave a tip.  I honestly think the people working here have put my name on their blacklist.  OK -- so I have been going to this particular noah's bagel for about 1 whole year, 2-4 times a week!  so the people working here DEFINATELY know me, my name and my face.  AND they know that I never tip -- because like i said before -- i never carry cash, only plastic, and they don't give me the option to tip with plastic, so i figure it's not my choice or fault.  well -- after todays' experience, i am never going back there again -- i will try House of Bagels instead (they did indeed bake our wedding challah, and it was yummy).  so let me tell you what happened today.  well for the 3rd time they gave me veggie or lox schmear instead of sundried tomato scmear, which i specifically requested on my bagel.  the first time this happened, i was in the car already, and it was gross that they would put slamon lox schmear on an everything bagel veg-out (yuck!), too bad i was starving, pregnant, and in a hurry to get to my massage at mindful body, tat i just had to gobble it down.  the 2nd time this happened, they put veggie schmear on my everything bagel veg-out instead of sun-dried tomato, this time i specifically requested no onions, and i had to eat that too because again i was aleady in the car on my way to another massage, the poor masseuse had to smell my onion breathe the whole hour.  so, today, and the 3rd time this happened, i actually checked my bagel before i got into my car, and lo and behold, again it had the wrong schmear, i mean these pople should know me by now -- i order the same thing every time (2-4 times a week), i order a veg-out on an everything bagel with sun-dried tomato schmear -- you would think they would have figured it out by now.  that's not all -- when i brought my bagel back today -- they guy actually told me that he put veggie schmear instead of sun-dried tomato schmear.  AND after i ordered, i hear my name whispered 3 times to the different people behind the counter -- as though to say, yep this is the gal who's bagel we usually screw up on purpose because she doesn't ever tip us.  ALSO,  they have repeatedly forgotten my pickle, once i actually ate in the store, and brought it up, and they were very rude about giving it to me -- as if.....and if i recall correctly the bagel mishap happened not 3 but 4 times -- so i've had it -- i will not give them my $$$ anymore, they are crap anyway, the only reason why i went there was because it was close to my prenatal yoga at the JCCSF up the street.  i wish i remembered the crew people's names, so i could name them here -- but trust me when i tell you that numerous people have screwed up my bagel -- it's like they really did mark my name up.  so beware this place -- the bagels suck, the customer service sucks, and they hold a vendetta and a grudge just because you pay via credit card.  would not recommend.
author: Jordan F.
